metadata.titleEn: Frozen depth of frozen ground in Hulugou sub-basin of the Heihe River Basin (2013)
metadata.description:
1. Data overview:
This data set is the data set of frozen depth of permafrost observed artificially in qilian station from January 1, 2013 to December 31, 2013, and observed at 08 o 'clock every day.
2. Data content:
The data content is the frozen depth data set of the tundra.The frozen depth (length) of the water in the inner rubber tube is used as a record to determine the freezing level and the upper and lower depth of the frozen layer according to the freezing position and length of the water in the frozen pot.In centimeters (cm), round off the whole number and round off the decimal.Observe once a day at 0:8.
3. Space and time range:
Geographical coordinates: longitude: 99° 53’e;Latitude: 38°16 'N;Height: 2981.0 m
metadata.instructions: Data file name: hulugou basin frozen depth data set in 2013.xlsx; it can be viewed and edited by WPS or excel.

background: Understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff is critical for sustainable water management especially in arid inland river basins such as those in northwest China where water resources mainly come from alpine areas. The Earth’s cryosphere is facing rapid changes in the duration, extent, and mass of snow and ice, which have had multiple impacts on the environment across a range of temporal and spatial scales. Changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost have resulted in significant downstream impacts in terms of the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. This shrinkage has modified the water cycle and river discharge in cold regions and caused the rise of global mean sea level. Serving as a solid reservoir for many endorheic and exorheic basins, the mountain cryosphere is the regulator of major rivers and provides most of the water resources in arid regions in China and its neighboring countries. However, because of inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, the significance of the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences remain unclear in China.
research objective: The scientific objective of the CHOICE is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions. Four key science questions have been identified: The spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation need to be determined. The effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow need to be determined. The effects of changes in the vegetation pattern in the vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff in the mountains must be assessed. A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas.
challenges: Understanding such changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.
methods: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of the following meteorological variables: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. We also conducted long-term standard meteorological field (SMF) manual observations for reference to those obtained at AWS. The total discharge has been monitored by a continuously stream-gauging station at the catchment outlet since 2009. From 2009 to 2012, we also manually used the float protocol and a stopwatch to estimate the nonfreezing period discharge in a meadow subcatchment and a moraine–talus subcatchment. To apply hydrological models in the alpine catchment, we have obtained long-term continuous soil parameter data in the soil pit synchronously with those collected at AWS. An SI-111 infrared radiometer (Apogee Instr. Inc.) was used to measure the LST. During the early stage of the CHOICE, evapotranspiration was measured with two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter and were installed in the SMF at the Hulu-1 field on 1 July 2009 with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) in precision. With the development of the CHOICE, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS of the Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 field in August 2013. An EC150 system (Campbell Scientific Inc.) was installed on a lattice mast at 5.8 m at the Hulu-2 field in September 2011. Four cluster wells were installed in 2011 and 2014 for groundwater monitoring and sampling. On fixed-point scale, six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) measure snow depth synchronously with AWS. In this system, three thermistor cables were installed that crossed the riverbed–water, water–ice, and ice–air interfaces. We conduct the work of precipitation intercomparisons by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment were performed with six total rain-weighing sensors (TRwS204, MPS System Ltd) with a single alter shield and synchronized with AWS. Fourteen LST observation sites with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes were built around the Hulu-3 field. Two LST observation sites were built to analyze the influences of plants on LST. To study the runoff process of canopy precipitation to surface runoff in different landscapes, two runoff fields (shrubs and meadows) (15 by 3 m) were established at a shrub-encroached alpine meadow hillslope in September 2010. Four methods were used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in the Hulu-1 field including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. Groundwater samples used for isotope analysis were collected from 12 wells between 2014 and 2016, and stream water samples were collected from 12 sites that were approximately evenly distributed from upstream to downstream between 2011 and 2016. A Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzer with a re-entry control system and six respiration chambers installed on the permafrost zone of the Hulu catchment in August 2017. The observation period of canopy precipitation interception began in June 2010. A total of four sap flow sensors (CAF, ECOMATIK) were installed to estimate transpiration. Variations in the diversity of the soil microbial community under meadow, shrub, marshy meadow, and moraine–talus were observed along an elevation gradient in the Hulu catchment in July 2013. An AWS was erected at the top of the glacier (4817 m asl) in September 2015; the site is not affected by the surrounding mountains. To obtain reliable turbulent data, EC system measurements were made adjacent to the AWS at a height of 4 m beginning in October 2017. To harvest the water contained in fog, five identical standard fog collectors were installed at Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 in July 2014. A warming simulation experiment was begun in September 2016. Two flight campaigns were performed in the Hulu catchment.
findings: In recent years, a series of studies have been published using the CHOICE sharing platform data, and a number of researchers have used the CHOICE data for studies of alpine meteorology, cryospheric hydrology, groundwater, soils, and isotopes. According to the six AWS of the CHOICE obtained throughout the Hulu catchment and peripheral precipitation data from five China Meteorological Administration stations (Zhangye, Minle, Sunan, Qilian, and Yeniugou), two or more yearly EMPs exist in the northern Qilian Mountains. A diminished accumulation zone will result in a reduction in the transport and expansion of the glaciers, and then the glaciers will have to retreat to limit themselves to reduce ablation. Based on 10-yr observations in the western cold regions of China, especially those obtained in the Upper Hei River basin (UHR), a new CBHM was created to evaluate the effects of cryospheric changes on stream flow from the UHR. In the past 50 yr, river runoff has generally shown an increasing trend as a result of increased rainfall, snowfall, and glacial runoff in the cold regions of western China.

Definition.Question: What does 'cryospheric hydrology' mean in the context of water resource management in alpine regions?
Definition.Answer: Cryospheric hydrology refers to the study of the hydrological processes involving snow, glaciers, and permafrost in the Earth's cryosphere. It focuses on understanding the impacts of cryospheric changes on water resources, particularly in alpine regions where these components regulate river runoff and provide essential water resources.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'AWS' in the context of environmental data collection?
Definition.Answer: AWS stands for Automatic Weather Station, a data collection method used for the long-term monitoring of various meteorological variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, radiation, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection challenges between measuring precipitation in mountainous regions using standard meteorological field observations versus automated rainfall sensors?
Comparison.Answer: Standard meteorological field observations rely on manual, often less frequent measurements, which can miss short-term variability but may be more accurate for specific events. Automated rainfall sensors, while providing continuous data and capturing more variability, can suffer from calibration issues and may be less accurate in extreme conditions such as high winds or intense snowfall.

Interpretation.Question: How do the variations in freezing depth measurements throughout the year inform the understanding of permafrost dynamics in mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The variations in freezing depth measurements can indicate the temporal changes in permafrost stability and responsiveness to climatic variables in mountainous regions. Observing the freeze and thaw cycles at daily intervals provides insights into seasonal dynamics and long-term changes, which can be crucial for evaluating cryospheric changes and their impact on local hydrology and ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise in accurately measuring the effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow, and how can data collection methods address these challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the remoteness of regions, sparse observations, and significant biases in precipitation data. Addressing these through comprehensive and synchronized data collection methods, such as the use of automated weather stations (AWS), stream-gauging stations, and various sensors for long-term monitoring, can help provide more accurate assessments of cryospheric impacts on hydrology.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the integration of diverse meteorological and hydrological data enhance the modeling of water resource changes in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating diverse data sources, such as AWS meteorological data, soil moisture, snow depth, and groundwater measurements, enhances the modeling of water resources by providing a holistic view of the hydrological cycle. This aids in understanding how cryospheric changes, precipitation patterns, and land cover variations collectively influence water availability and distribution in arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of understanding cryospheric changes in remote regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Understanding changes in remote regions is challenging due to their remoteness and sparse observations, and precipitation observations are beset with significant biases and errors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are comprehensive observation data considered essential for evaluating the effects of cryospheric changes on water resources in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Comprehensive observation data are essential to determine hydrological processes in mountainous regions and evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in lower arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for different methods to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in mountainous catchments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Different methods are required due to the varied landscape zones, such as alpine meadows and shrub-encroached hillslopes, which influence water balance and runoff processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of manual observation of frozen soil depth on the accuracy and reliability of permafrost data collection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Manual observation of frozen soil depth, as done daily at 08:00 using the freezing depth of water in rubber tubes, provides precise measurements in centimeters with rounding. However, this method may introduce human error and is limited by the frequency and timing of observations, potentially affecting the overall accuracy and temporal resolution of the permafrost data collected.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of various meteorological variables from AWS impact the understanding of hydrological processes in mountainous regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of data from AWS, which monitors variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, soil moisture, and snow depth, enhances the understanding of hydrological processes by providing comprehensive, continuous environmental data. This allows for better assessment of the effects of cryospheric and climate changes on streamflow and water resources in mountainous regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the key objectives behind collecting data on frozen soil depths in mountainous cryospheric regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The key objectives include understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff, which is critical for sustainable water management, especially in arid inland river basins. This data helps in determining the hydrological processes in mountainous regions and evaluating the impacts of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on water resources.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to implement diverse data collection methods, such as automated weather stations and manual observations, in alpine regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Implementing diverse data collection methods is important due to the challenges posed by the remoteness and sparse observations in alpine regions. These methods provide comprehensive observation data on various environmental factors, which are essential to address significant biases and errors in precipitation observations and to improve the understanding of cryospheric changes and their impacts on hydrology.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures and instruments used to measure and record the freezing depth of permafrost in a mountainous region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The freezing depth of permafrost is measured using a device that utilizes water frozen in a rubber inner tube as a record. The depths are determined based on the location and length of ice formation within the device embedded in the soil. The data is recorded in centimeters, rounded to the nearest whole number, with observations taken daily at 08:00 hours.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods and instruments are employed to monitor and analyze the effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow in alpine catchments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To monitor and analyze cryospheric changes on streamflow, long-term meteorological variables such as air temperature, soil moisture, and snow depth are recorded using an Automatic Weather Station (AWS). Stream-gauging stations monitor total discharge continuously, and additional manual methods like float protocols are used for estimating nonfreezing period discharge. Instruments like thermistor cables, SI-111 infrared radiometers, and EC150 systems (for turbulence data) are also utilized.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are precipitation and snow depth measured and compared across different sites in an alpine catchment?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Precipitation measurements are performed using rain-weighing sensors synchronized with AWS, while snow depth is measured using SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors. Precipitation intercomparisons are conducted using pit gauges and double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauges as part of the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO. Observation sites with varying elevations and aspects are established to capture diverse data points.

Enablement.Question: What resources or techniques enable the accurate measurement of frozen soil depth in remote areas like the Hulu catchment?
Enablement.Answer: The measurement of frozen soil depth is enabled by utilizing a method where the freezing depth of water filled in a rubber inner tube is recorded. The frozen layers and their depth limits are determined by observing the ice formation within the buried soil frost device.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or technologies are necessary to facilitate the comprehensive study of cryospheric hydrology impacts on river runoff in mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: The study of cryospheric hydrology impacts is facilitated by deploying long-term monitoring technologies like AWS, soil parameter data collection, snow depth sensors, and hydrological models. Additionally, addressing biases in precipitation observations and sparse data challenges are crucial conditions for such studies.

Expectation.Question: Why might long-term continuous soil parameter data be crucial for understanding hydrological processes in cryospheric regions?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term continuous soil parameter data is crucial because it allows researchers to apply hydrological models effectively in alpine catchments, offering insights into the interactions between soil and cryospheric elements, which can impact water resources and hydrological cycles.

Expectation.Question: Why are precipitation observations in alpine regions often subject to significant biases and errors?
Expectation.Answer: Precipitation observations in alpine regions are often subject to biases and errors due to the remote nature and sparse distribution of observation sites, as well as the complex topography which can affect the accuracy of measurement tools and techniques.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of the data collection methods used for measuring cryospheric changes and their impact on water resources?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods utilized, such as long-term monitoring with automatic weather stations (AWS), field manual observations, and various sensors for soil moisture, snow depth, and land surface temperature, provide comprehensive datasets. However, challenges remain due to the remoteness of these regions and sparse observations, which may introduce biases and errors in precipitation measurements.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges faced in collecting reliable data on cryospheric hydrology in alpine regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Collecting reliable data in alpine regions is challenging due to their remoteness and sparse observational infrastructure. Although advanced technology and various measurement tools have been deployed, issues such as significant biases and errors in precipitation observations still persist, making it difficult to fully understand hydrological changes in these vulnerable regions.

Judgmental.Question: Can the current datasets effectively address the impacts of cryospheric changes on river runoff in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The current datasets, derived from comprehensive observation systems such as AWS and other monitoring tools, have been crucial for studying cryospheric hydrology and its effects on river runoff. However, due to inadequate observation data and limited regional-scale knowledge, the full significance and severity of cryospheric impacts on river runoff in arid regions remain unclear.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how data collection methods can accurately measure environmental factors in remote alpine regions with sparse observations.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods in such regions often involve the use of Automated Weather Stations (AWS) that monitor various meteorological variables, along with manual observations for reference. Challenges include the remoteness and sparse observations, which can lead to biases and errors in data collection.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how different methods are used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in varied landscapes.
Assertion.Answer: Different methods such as single-ring and double-ring infiltrometers, Hood infiltrometer, and ring cutter method are used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity. These methods are applied to understand how different landscapes affect water movement and storage in the soil.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the various data collection methods used to measure cryospheric changes and their impacts on hydrology and water resources in alpine regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods in the field involve the use of automatic weather stations (AWS) for monitoring meteorological variables such as air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and precipitation. There are also manual observations for reference, continuous stream-gauging stations for discharge monitoring, and various instruments like infrared radiometers for land surface temperature measurement. Additionally, multiple sensors and microlysimeters are used to monitor soil moisture, evapotranspiration, and snow depth. Groundwater monitoring is conducted through wells, and isotope analysis is performed on samples collected from various sites.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the challenges faced in collecting accurate and comprehensive cryospheric data in remote alpine regions and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting cryospheric data include the remoteness of regions, sparse observations, and significant biases in precipitation data. Potential solutions might include the deployment of more AWS for comprehensive data collection, improving methodologies for precipitation measurement such as using pit gauges and double reference intercomparison gauges, and increasing the number of observation sites to cover varied elevations, aspects, and slopes.
